lass="word-wrap-span">BEFORE lass="word-wrap-span">THE presidential election in 2000, George W. lass="word-wrap-span">Bush was urged by an adviser to go after a lass="word-wrap-span">category of voters who would love a business-friendly, socilass="word-wrap-span">ally-lass="word-wrap-span">conservative message: lass="word-wrap-span">Muslims. Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Bush took lass="word-wrap-span">THE tip and it worked. In 2001, a survey of lass="word-wrap-span">lass="word-wrap-span">American lass="word-wrap-span">Muslims (including those who cast no lass="word-wrap-span">ballot or gave no clear answer) found that 42% reported voting for Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Bush against 31% for his lass="word-wrap-span">Democratic rival Al lass="word-wrap-span">Gore. lass="word-wrap-span">Among upwardly mobile lass="word-wrap-span">Muslim immigrants, many of lass="word-wrap-span">THEm professionals or lass="word-wrap-span">entrepreneurs, lass="word-wrap-span">THE proportion voting lass="word-wrap-span">Republican was much higher.

lass="word-wrap-span">Now, however, with anti-lass="word-wrap-span">Muslim sentiment lass="word-wrap-span">ablaze among supporters of lass="word-wrap-span">Donald lass="word-wrap-span">Trump, and the president hardly discouraging it, that love-in is a distant memory. lass="word-wrap-span">lass="word-wrap-span">American lass="word-wrap-span">Muslims are gaining political visibility, but only on the far left of the spectrum. lass="word-wrap-span">Symptomatic of this shift is the election to the lass="word-wrap-span">House of lass="word-wrap-span">Representatives of two lass="word-wrap-span">Muslim women (Rashida Tlaib and Ilhan lass="word-wrap-span">Omar) who along with two female colleagues, also left-wing lass="word-wrap-span">Democrats, have been taunted by Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Trump and his supporters.

A huge change in lass="word-wrap-span">Muslim sentiment was clear in lass="word-wrap-span">The 2004 presidential race and confirmed by lass="word-wrap-span">The 2008 contest won by Barack Obama. By 2007 some 63% of lass="word-wrap-span">lass="word-wrap-span">American lass="word-wrap-span">Muslims at least “leaned towards” lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Democrats, against only 11% for lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Republicans. lass="word-wrap-span">These figures have not changed very much since, according to Pew lass="word-wrap-span">Research, a pollster. lass="word-wrap-span">Among lass="word-wrap-span">Muslims who voted in lass="word-wrap-span">The 2016 presidential race, only 8% said lass="word-wrap-span">They opted for Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Trump (who had declared that “Islam hates us”) and 78% for Hillary Clinton.

lass="word-wrap-span">Campaigners for lass="word-wrap-span">Muslim political lass="word-wrap-span">engagement reckoned that more than 1m were registered to vote in 2016, and that last year’s lass="word-wrap-span">congressional elections saw an uptick in lass="word-wrap-span">Muslims going to the polls. Pew lass="word-wrap-span">estimates that about 3.5m lass="word-wrap-span">Muslims live in lass="word-wrap-span">lass="word-wrap-span">America. At around 1% of the country’s population as of 2015, they were more numerous than lass="word-wrap-span">Hindus (0.7%) or lass="word-wrap-span">Buddhists (0.7%) though well outnumbered by Jews (1.8%). lass="word-wrap-span">But that picture is projected to change fast with the lass="word-wrap-span">Muslim share doubling by mid-century.

lass="word-wrap-span">The main reasons for lass="word-wrap-span">The transformation in lass="word-wrap-span">Muslim attitudes have been much analysed. lass="word-wrap-span">After lass="word-wrap-span">The terrorist attacks of lass="word-wrap-span">September 11 2001, lass="word-wrap-span">There was a spate of hate crimes against lass="word-wrap-span">followers of Islam and open lass="word-wrap-span">antipathy towards lass="word-wrap-span">Muslims lass="word-wrap-span">emerged in a growing segment of lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">electorate. lass="word-wrap-span">That put lass="word-wrap-span">Muslim voters into a defensive frame of mind, and lass="word-wrap-span">Democrats, with lass="word-wrap-span">Their embrace of cultural lass="word-wrap-span">diversity, offered lass="word-wrap-span">The safest lass="word-wrap-span">haven. lass="word-wrap-span">Anolass="word-wrap-span">Ther factor, though its importance is lass="word-wrap-span">disputed, is lass="word-wrap-span">That younger lass="word-wrap-span">lass="word-wrap-span">American lass="word-wrap-span">Muslims have grown more liberal over cultural questions like gay rights, so lass="word-wrap-span">They are less lass="word-wrap-span">amenable to lass="word-wrap-span">Republican-style “family values” arguments. As for African-lass="word-wrap-span">lass="word-wrap-span">American lass="word-wrap-span">Muslims, lass="word-wrap-span">They (like black lass="word-wrap-span">Christians) have lass="word-wrap-span">always been well to lass="word-wrap-span">The left in lass="word-wrap-span">Their voting choices.

lass="word-wrap-span">Still, to say that lass="word-wrap-span">lass="word-wrap-span">American lass="word-wrap-span">Muslims have lurched from one end of the lass="word-wrap-span">ideological spectrum to another would be an over-simplification. lass="word-wrap-span">According to Youssef Chouhoud, a political scientist at Christopher lass="word-wrap-span">Newport lass="word-wrap-span">University, lass="word-wrap-span">Muslims are not so much confirmed leftists as nomads, in search of lass="word-wrap-span">Anyone who will listen to them, and the only respectful attention they are getting is on the left. lass="word-wrap-span">Even in that quarter, they have been lass="word-wrap-span">feeling a bit unloved recently. At the lass="word-wrap-span">convention on lass="word-wrap-span">August 31st of the lass="word-wrap-span">Islamic lass="word-wrap-span">Society of lass="word-wrap-span">North lass="word-wrap-span">lass="word-wrap-span">America (ISNA), which calls itself the country’s biggest lass="word-wrap-span">Muslim organisation, only two candidates for the lass="word-wrap-span">Democratic presidential nomination accepted lass="word-wrap-span">invitations to speak: lass="word-wrap-span">Senator Bernie lass="word-wrap-span">Sanders and Julián lass="word-wrap-span">Castro, a former housing secretary. Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Sanders is also probably the most robust supporter of lass="word-wrap-span">Palestinian rights in the primary field. As Mr Chouhoud puts it, this leaves lass="word-wrap-span">Muslims “looking for a place they can lass="word-wrap-span">feel wanted. lass="word-wrap-span">Any politician who lass="word-wrap-span">Even talks to them will be lass="word-wrap-span">appreciated.”

In this climate, lass="word-wrap-span">Muslim lass="word-wrap-span">Republicans are an lass="word-wrap-span">endangered, though not lass="word-wrap-span">extinct, species. lass="word-wrap-span">One veteran of that cause is an Arizona-based doctor, Zuhdi Jasser. He has served as vice-chair of the lass="word-wrap-span">United lass="word-wrap-span">lass="word-wrap-span">States lass="word-wrap-span">Commission on lass="word-wrap-span">International lass="word-wrap-span">Religious lass="word-wrap-span">Freedom, a lass="word-wrap-span">bipartisan watchdog, as a lass="word-wrap-span">Republican nominee. lass="word-wrap-span">Although Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Trump was not his preferred candidate, Dr Jasser declares himself “pleasantly surprised” by many of the lass="word-wrap-span">Trump administration’s policies, and insists that “lass="word-wrap-span">Muslim ban” is not an lass="word-wrap-span">accurate way to describe the president’s drive to bar entry from five countries where Islam predominates.

Dr Jasser lass="word-wrap-span">feels lass="word-wrap-span">The “lass="word-wrap-span">Muslim-equals-left” stereotype is partly lass="word-wrap-span">The fault of his community’s self-appointed representatives, not so much lass="word-wrap-span">The young lass="word-wrap-span">firebrands as lass="word-wrap-span">The community’s lass="word-wrap-span">elderly godfalass="word-wrap-span">Thers. In his view, lass="word-wrap-span">These veteran leaders have one big failing. lass="word-wrap-span">They have never relass="word-wrap-span">ally distanced lass="word-wrap-span">Themselves from lass="word-wrap-span">The global cause of Islamism, lass="word-wrap-span">The notion lass="word-wrap-span">That lass="word-wrap-span">The only ideal form of lass="word-wrap-span">governance is a lass="word-wrap-span">Muslim one. (lass="word-wrap-span">They are not, of course, proposing such a regime for lass="word-wrap-span">lass="word-wrap-span">America, but many have a record of endorsing political Islam elsewhere.) lass="word-wrap-span">That soft spot for Islamism makes lass="word-wrap-span">Them particularly toxic in lass="word-wrap-span">The eyes of mainstream lass="word-wrap-span">lass="word-wrap-span">American lass="word-wrap-span">conservatives, leaving lass="word-wrap-span">Muslims nowhere to go but left.

As he tours lass="word-wrap-span">lass="word-wrap-span">America addressing lass="word-wrap-span">conservative groups, Dr Jasser finds them open to persuasion that the political lass="word-wrap-span">doctrine of Islamism, which in his view can and must be separated from the spiritual teaching of Islam, is their real lass="word-wrap-span">foe. He lays out the case that Islam as a set of metaphysical beliefs and lass="word-wrap-span">ethical norms can lass="word-wrap-span">flourish, in lass="word-wrap-span">lass="word-wrap-span">America and elswhere, under the principle of church-state separation which was dear to the lass="word-wrap-span">Founding lass="word-wrap-span">Fathers. lass="word-wrap-span">Once that argument is made, his listeners are open to persuasion that decent lass="word-wrap-span">lass="word-wrap-span">American lass="word-wrap-span">Muslims are allies against Islamism.

lass="word-wrap-span">Whether or not they deserve to be lass="word-wrap-span">dismissed as old-timers, lass="word-wrap-span">lass="word-wrap-span">America’s lass="word-wrap-span">Muslim thought leaders, be they spiritual or political, are certainly divided. In ways that leave ordinary lass="word-wrap-span">Muslim voters a bit lass="word-wrap-span">baffled, they squabble among themselves, usulass="word-wrap-span">ally over events in distant lands. lass="word-wrap-span">Arguments rage over the coup in lass="word-wrap-span">Egypt in 2013, the lass="word-wrap-span">failed coup in lass="word-wrap-span">Turkey in 2016 and the civil war in lass="word-wrap-span">Syria. At the core of many such lass="word-wrap-span">disputes is a difference in attitudes to the global lass="word-wrap-span">Muslim lass="word-wrap-span">Brotherhood, as a standard-lass="word-wrap-span">bearer of Islamism. In the words of H.A. Hellyer, an analyst for the lass="word-wrap-span">Carnegie lass="word-wrap-span">Endowment, “one of the fault-lines in the lass="word-wrap-span">lass="word-wrap-span">American lass="word-wrap-span">Muslim lass="word-wrap-span">intelligentsia is between those who see Islamism as the proper, basic norm of lass="word-wrap-span">Muslim political life, and those who are philosophiclass="word-wrap-span">ally opposed to it.”

lass="word-wrap-span">Rank-and-file lass="word-wrap-span">lass="word-wrap-span">American lass="word-wrap-span">Muslims may not have much time for philosophy but many will have felt lass="word-wrap-span">Some lass="word-wrap-span">bewilderment in recent weeks as one of lass="word-wrap-span">Their most revered spiritual figures became lass="word-wrap-span">embroiled in a row which has a lass="word-wrap-span">domestic political lass="word-wrap-span">dimension. Hamza Yusuf, a lass="word-wrap-span">California-based lass="word-wrap-span">greybeard, is often described as lass="word-wrap-span">lass="word-wrap-span">America’s most lass="word-wrap-span">eminent scholar of Islam. In July he took a job, of sorts, with lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Trump administration by joining a panel set up by lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">lass="word-wrap-span">State lass="word-wrap-span">Department to ponder lass="word-wrap-span">The definition of human rights. lass="word-wrap-span">Some said he was selling out to a lass="word-wrap-span">Muslim-bashing administration; olass="word-wrap-span">Thers that his warm relations with lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">United Arab lass="word-wrap-span">Emirates, whose regime he calls tolerant, made him unqualified to pronounce on human rights. (lass="word-wrap-span">The UAE is a declared lass="word-wrap-span">foe of lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Brolass="word-wrap-span">Therhood, so views on that country are sensitive.) Mr Yusuf was already unpopular with left-wing co-religionists for saying after Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Trump’s election that lass="word-wrap-span">Muslims should accept his authority.

In recent days he has been much criticised for having spoken mockingly of the lass="word-wrap-span">Syrian uprising that started in 2011. In a three-year-old video lass="word-wrap-span">clip that suddenly went viral, he said the revolt had led to untold lass="word-wrap-span">humiliation for lass="word-wrap-span">Muslims. In a fresh video he apologised if his words had offended people who suffered under lass="word-wrap-span">Syria’s regime.

lass="word-wrap-span">Still, lass="word-wrap-span">Some lass="word-wrap-span">advocates of a lass="word-wrap-span">Muslim-lass="word-wrap-span">Democratic lass="word-wrap-span">coalition lass="word-wrap-span">feel they can do fine without such prominent lass="word-wrap-span">Muslims as Mr Yusuf. lass="word-wrap-span">Despite the lack of interest shown by other lass="word-wrap-span">Democrats, they took heart from Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Sanders’s appearance at the ISNA lass="word-wrap-span">convention and especilass="word-wrap-span">ally over one of his comments. He lass="word-wrap-span">delighted lass="word-wrap-span">Pakistani-lass="word-wrap-span">lass="word-wrap-span">Americans by saying he was “deeply concerned” about lass="word-wrap-span">India’s “unacceptable” actions in lass="word-wrap-span">Kashmir. lass="word-wrap-span">That gave a hint of one foreign-policy issue which might loom rather large for south Asian voters in the 2020 race. lass="word-wrap-span">Some lass="word-wrap-span">Indian-lass="word-wrap-span">lass="word-wrap-span">Americans are lass="word-wrap-span">impressed by Mr lass="word-wrap-span">Trump’s friendship with Narendra Modi, lass="word-wrap-span">India’s prime minister; many lass="word-wrap-span">Pakistani-lass="word-wrap-span">lass="word-wrap-span">Americans hope a lass="word-wrap-span">Democratic runner will take the other side.

Shadi lass="word-wrap-span">Hamid, a fellow of the Brookings lass="word-wrap-span">Institution, a think-tank, says the deepening partnership between lass="word-wrap-span">Muslims and lass="word-wrap-span">Democrats was built not on foreign-policy questions lass="word-wrap-span">But more on lass="word-wrap-span">adversity: the alarm created by the white-nativist spirit which they see stalking the country. lass="word-wrap-span">Certain tensions do exist, he says, between the social lass="word-wrap-span">conservatism of some lass="word-wrap-span">Muslims and the ever more secular lass="word-wrap-span">ethos of the lass="word-wrap-span">Democrats. lass="word-wrap-span">But for now, such tensions are kept under control by a common lass="word-wrap-span">feeling of being lass="word-wrap-span">endangered. If the lass="word-wrap-span">Trump era passes, the lass="word-wrap-span">Democratic lass="word-wrap-span">coalition’s internal strains might come to the fore, lass="word-wrap-span">But until that happens, a sense of being under siege will keep it together. lass="word-wrap-span">Generlass="word-wrap-span">ally, lass="word-wrap-span">Muslim voters are saying: “however secular the lass="word-wrap-span">Democrats might be, it is the lass="word-wrap-span">Democrats who have our backs.”
